title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act titled "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" requires drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of state TANF assistance programs. States must certify the operation of an illegal drug screening and testing program for individuals at high risk of substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of state TANF assistance programs to identify high-risk individuals for substance abuse. The program may include continued random or scheduled testing after the initial screening at the discretion of the State agency. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals applying for or receiving state TANF assistance. State agencies must screen individuals for illegal drug use and test those identified as high-risk for substance abuse. Grants under section 403 cannot be used to assist individuals who have not undergone screening or necessary testing for illegal drug use. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for individuals seeking or receiving state TANF assistance. Screening is done through an effective survey to identify substance abuse risk, followed by further evaluation if needed. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals receiving state TANF assistance. Screening is conducted through a survey or test to assess the risk of substance abuse, with further evaluation if necessary. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals receiving state TANF assistance. Screening is conducted to assess the risk of substance abuse, with further evaluation if necessary. If found to have a high risk of substance abuse, individuals are tested for illegal drug use. The term 'illegal drug' refers to a controlled substance as defined in the Controlled Substances Act. The Secretary cannot waive the provisions of drug screening and testing. If assistance is denied, the State must continue to provide assistance for other family members. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals receiving state TANF assistance. If an individual is denied assistance, the State must continue to provide assistance for other family members. Amendments made by this section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. The State plan under section 402(a) of the Social Security Act must meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments made by this Act by the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter beginning after the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature that begins after the date of enactment. The State plan must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature after the enactment of this Act.
